title: GLOBAL GEEKEND Creative Coast showcases Savannah's innovators
text:
G eekend, the Creative Coast’s tech and interactive design conference, proved the importance of showcasing entrepreneurs in front of potential investors.
Last Thursday, as the seventh annual Geekend opened, Brian Bason was awarded $50,000 to help develop a new product for his firm, Bark.
Bason, along with four other entrepreneurs, pitched their business ideas during Pitch Circus. Bason’s software product, which helps keep children safe from online dangers such as cyberbullying and online predators, won over the crowd along with investor and Guild Hall co-owner Clegg Ivey
“I was so impressed with what Brian had to say about Bark that not only are we going to give Bark status as one of (The Guild ) portfolio companies, but I’m ready to write a check for $50,000,” Ivey said to a booming round of applause.
The Guild Hall partnered with Creative Coast to present Geekend.
The Creative Coast’s teaming with The Guild Hall makes sense. The nonprofit’s mission is to create more connective tissue among entrepreneurs, designers, developers, marketers and other creatives by bringing them together and engaging them in meaningful conversations.
The Guild Hall provides the space for creative individuals that allow its members to play, create and network on its four-building campus. The space boasts a makerspace, a black box theater, several computer labs and other creative spaces were a perfect fit for Geekend.
Creative Coast is in part funded by the city of Savannah and the Savannah Economic Development Authority, a good investment for both organizations.
Geekend attract a global audience that includes innovators, investors, and a host of creatives from such diverse locales as South Dakota, Estonia and Seattle.
The topics provide a wide array for those interested in the creative world. Among the subjects discussed were: the future of health care technology; intellectual property law; the power of storytelling; and the latest in education technology.
One of the high profile speakers at the conference was Federal Communications commission Ajit Pai. The FCC plays a key role in enabling digital opportunity by promoting investment in the nation’s next-generation broadband networks and by freeing up more spectrums for consumers’ use.
You don’t’ have to be a geek to attend Geekend or even appreciate its value to the community. With its lineup of speakers and topics, the conference shows how entrepreneurship is as important to today’s digital world as it was when Johannes Gutenberg invented the printing press.
